ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
PUBLIC ASSISTANCE ALLOWANCES
(Increase of rates and payment facilities)


    1. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs if the Government will consider increasing the rates of Public Assistance Allowances and if he will set up payment centres in all the 51 constituencies for the convenience of the recipients and to save them expense on transport in having to go to the Social Welfare Department in Havelock Road.

    The Minister for Culture and Social Affairs (Inche Othman Bin Wok): Mr Speaker, Sir, since the P.A.P. Government assumed office in June 1959, the rates of public assistance allowance given to the head of household have been increased twice from - $15 to $16 in September 1959, and again from $16 to $21 in January 1962. The allowance for the wife was also increased from $8 to $10 per month as from September 1959.

    As the existing rates of public assistance are the highest in this part of the world, it is not considered prudent in the interests of our economy to make further increases which can only be done if we raise more taxes, in 1966 a sum of $8,262,815.95 cents was paid to 22,241 families on the public assistance scheme.

    At present there are 41 public assistance payment centres situated in all parts of the island, apart from the payment centre at the Social Welfare Department at Havelock Road, in addition, there are mobile payment teams that go to the neighbouring islands, hospitals, homes for the aged, and to the individual homes of those recipients who are unable to get to the payment centres to receive their public assistance allowance. As these payment centres have been so located for the convenience of the recipients with a view to lessening their expense on transport

Column: 725

to get to the centres, and they are adequate to serve the localities where they are situated, Government considers it unnecessary to establish payment centres on the basis of division of constituencies.

    For the information of the Member for Thomson, the 42 payment centres are located in 33 constituencies, which means that in certain constituencies there is more than one payment centre.

    Mr Ang Nam Piau (Thomson): Can the Minister concerned give the House the different rates of assistance and the names of the constituencies in which the Social Welfare Department has established payment centres?

    Mr Speaker: Inche Othman, even if you have the information now, it might perhaps be best if you circulate it in the Official Report.

ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE FOR 1968


    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [2nd Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



2.34 p.m.

    Head 0601 -

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, 1 beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0601 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1001+.
+ The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr. Lim Guan Hoo.


    Sir, having gone through all the heads of expenditure of the various Ministries in the 1968 Estimates, I am drawn to some curious footnotes that appear on pages 153, 155, 156, 158, 159 and 161 which explain the posts of some of the officers in the Ministry of Education who are drawing, in addition to a salary, certain allowances. For example, a footnote appearing in page 153 states:

    '(v) In certain cases, holders of these posts draw in addition pensionable allowances of $120, $180, $240, or $300 p.m.'.

Sir, I have been trying to find out whether other Ministries have payments of these so-called pensionable allowances. In fact, I believe I can see none. I suppose these so-called pensionable allowances are given to certain officers who have been promoted, say, from the post of teacher to principal, or lecturer, or school inspector, or specialist teacher. If my supposition is correct, I am inclined to believe that the payment of such kind of allowances is far from satisfactory. I would like to know whose brainchild it was to grant such pensionable allowances, and how much it has cost us each year when this system was instituted.

    Furthermore, is the Minister for Education aware that the other Ministries have no such system of pensionable allowances? To me, Sir, it would appear that any officer in the Ministry of Education who has been

Column: 727

promoted, be it to principal, inspector of school, specialist teacher, inspector, or lecturer, would automatically enjoy such benefit in pensionable allowances. However, I must stress that I am not against these civil servants obtaining any higher pay if they so deserve as a result of being promoted. Therefore, I would like to propose to the Minister for Education that this kind of payment be scrapped and in its place a proper salary structure be instituted so as to give not only uniformity in the salary structure but also opportunities to aspirants to reach the very top rung of the education ladder.

    Mr Lim Guan Hoo (Bukit Merah)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I agree with what the Member has said on the amendment. Not very long ago when the Minister for Education proposed the Nanyang University (Amendment) Bill, I pointed out that there was a loophole in it, namely, that there was only provision for a Vice-Chancellor without a Chancellor, although the Chairman of the Council, as stated by the Minister, was in name compatible with that of Chancellor. But actually the nature of the duties of the Chairman of the University Council was not suitable to make him a Chancellor of Nanyang University, because the Chairman of the Council shall be elected by the Council from among its members while a Chancellor is usually not appointed by election. The Minister did not take proper steps to amend the law but allowed it to remain as it was. Through his toleration, the designations of the Deputy Vice-Chancellor and the Vice-Chancellor have been officially announced to be the "Vice-Chancellor" and the "Chancellor" respectively in the text of Chinese translation. These difficulties arise when there is a translation from English to Chinese and vice versa.

    The Chairman: Mr Lim, you are speaking about a body set up by statute, and you are referring to matters which are not within the responsibility of the

Column: 728

Minister. So that no matter how long you speak on this, if the Minister stood up and said, "These are not matters within my responsibility," that would be an adequate reply. Can you please relate your remarks to his functions as Minister?

    Mr Lim Guan Hoo(In Mandarin): Sir, can the Minister pay special attention to what I have suggested and whether he will consider introducing amending legislation? Because of the technicalities of translation, there is confusion in the term "Vice-Chancellor", and I hope the Minister will do something about it, because the law was introduced by him and passed by this House. So I feel that he must look into this problem. And even though it may not be within his direct jurisdiction, he has the responsibility to see it rectified.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, as a graduate of Nanyang University, I think I have the duty to speak a few words on behalf of my University. As everybody knows ---

    Mr Lim Guan Hoo(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to clarify. If the Member wants to argue on behalf of the Minister, I think it is quite all right. But if he wants to argue on behalf of the University, I would like to ask whether that is permissible under our Standing Orders.

    The Chairman: Mr Lim, I have not yet heard what Mr Ho is going to say.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Member for Bukit Merah is rather sensitive.

    Sir, everybody knows that Nanyang University has been in existence for 11 years now. There have also been quite a number of graduation ceremonies - eight altogether. There are more than 3,000 Nanyang University graduates, some of whom have gone abroad, some are already working, and some are serving society. Many Nanyang graduates have achieved distinction in higher institutions abroad. There are also many eminent and successful

Column: 729

Nanyang graduates serving in various Government departments and commercial and industrial circles in every walk of life and their achievements can be seen by all to be quite meritorious.

    Although the Government is giving equal treatment to Nanyang graduates, when these graduates apply to join Government service, the Government seems to be hesitating about the recognition of Nanyang University degrees. The Government does not seem to have taken any decision on this matter, although in the past I have already said that this question is very pressing.

2.45 p.m.

    We can only hear the sound of Government promise without its being actually put into practice. If this problem is not solved, it will embarrass many of our Nanyang graduates who go abroad for further studies. The reason is that many foreign universities have recognised Nanyang graduates because they have achieved good academic results. Yet our own country is not giving them any recognition. Sir, after the reorganisation, Nanyang University has already been put on the right track. It is now prospering and marching along the right path. It holds out great promise for the future. I think the time has now come for Government to recognise Nanyang University degrees. I hope the Minister will try his best to help so that Nanyang University degrees will be recognised early and Nanyang University graduates will benefit from it. I am looking forward to this good news. Can the Minister tell us when the Government intends to help Nanyang University?

    The Minister for Education (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, the pensionable allowances referred to by the Member for Punggol is, in fact, known as "post allowances". The system of post allowances in the Education service was first introduced in October 1953 with retrospective effect to 1st January, 1950. It formed part of the overall salary revision which was

Column: 730

approved after negotiations between the then Government and the trade union then representing the teaching profession. The new salary scales and the post allowances were written into the Education service scheme forming part of the Scheme for Higher Services, 1953. In the course of negotiations, the Graduate Teachers' Association, which has since gone out of existence, played a prominent part. Under the scheme, post allowances ranging from $120 to $360 per month are attached to certain posts such as lecturers in the Teachers' Training College, Inspectors of Schools and principals of primary and secondary schools. These allowances become pensionable emoluments as soon as the officers concerned are emplaced on the pensionable establishment. In other words, for pensionable officers these allowances attract variable allowance in the same way as basic salary and are taken into account for purposes of computing pension and gratuity. This system of post allowances, I agree, has led to many anomalies in the service, chief among them being the fact that principals of secondary schools draw a higher rate of allowance than Inspectors of Schools when logically it should be the other way round. Because of different rates of allowances being attached to different posts of more or less the same responsibility, it is not possible to transfer officers of comparable qualifications and experience from one post to another in the interest of the service and of the officers themselves. I, therefore, agree with the Member for Punggol that the system of post allowances should be abolished in favour of different salary scales for different grades of officers with a variety of Posts requiring the same qualifications and experience within each grade. My Ministry has, in fact, made representations along these lines to the appropriate quarters and the outcome is being awaited.

    The Member for Bukit Merah has raised the question of the Chinese translation of the terms "Vice-Chancellor" and "Deputy Vice-Chancellor". Mr Speaker, Sir, the nominal head of a university is the

Column: 731

Chancellor whose functions are mainly statutory and ceremonial. The administrative and academic head of a university is the Vice-Chancellor whose duty it is to conduct the day-to-day affairs of a university. In Chinese universities, however, there is no post corresponding to that of a Chancellor and in Nanyang University there is also no provision for such a post. Consequently, the Vice-Chancellor of Nanyang University is designated in Chinese as "Head of the University", that is, Seow Chang, and the Deputy Vice-Chancellor is known in Chinese as "Deputy Head of the University", Fu Seow Chang, which in fact describe their respective functions accurately.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I quite sympathise with the Member for Jurong's concern over the question of recognition of Nanyang University degrees. In fact, this question has been receiving the attention of the Government for quite a considerable time. At the last convocation ceremony held in May 1967, I did make a statement that the question of recognition would be resolved in about two or three years' time. However, judging from the rare of progress in the University, both in the academic field as well as in University organisation, and also judging by the better qualified staff that are being recruited at the moment, I am quite prepared to say that the question of recognition of Nanyang degrees would be resolved by the next convocation, much earlier than what I had originally anticipated.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, we have been given a detailed explanation of a system that was instituted by the previous Government and which led to so many anomalies in the salary scales of the teaching profession. Schemes agreed to in January 1953 had retrospective effect to January 1950 -three years and it was known as the Singapore Education Service Scheme. The Minister has just explained that the Ministry is already aware of such a defect in the salary structure and has

Column: 732

written to some quarters making representations with a view to rectifying such anomalies. I shall be grateful if he will name the quarters and when this was done.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I cannot be held responsible for what took place way back in 1953 or 1950. Anyway, for the information of the Member for Punggol, the representation of my Ministry was made to the Salaries Commission.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: When will the report of the Salaries Commission be out, Sir?

    The Chairman: That question is best addressed to the Minister for Finance.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: I want a vote to be taken, Sir.

    Question on the amendment put, and negatived.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for [-lead 0601 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1219.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in the provision of the Estimates for 1968 in respect of teachers-in-training at the Teachers' Training College, it is noted that 1,495 posts had been abolished. In 1967 provision has been made for 4,082 teachers-in-training, whereas in 1968 Only 2,587 posts will be provided. Can the Minister clarify whether the abolition of the 1,495 posts means that there are more than sufficient teachers for all the schools in our Republic and that the intake of student teachers to undergo training at the Teachers' Training College in 1968 will be less by that number?

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, the decrease in the number of posts for teachers-in-training reflects the increasingly rapid reversion to full-time training in the Teachers' Training College. Unlike part-time trainees, full-time trainees are not paid a salary and consequently no posts need be entered in

Column: 733

the Estimates for them. That we are able to revert to full-time training shows that the part-time system of training introduced in 1960 has, to a large extent, overcome the teacher shortage. It is expected that no more part-time trainees need be recruited in the Chinese medium for primary schools next year, and the same situation will apply to the English medium part-time trainees in the next two or three years. It is confirmed that the reduction of 1,495 posts of teachers-in-training means that the intake of part-time trainees in the Teachers' Training College will be reduced by that number in 1968.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong: In view of the information given by the Minister, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0601 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1221.

    Sir, with the rise in the number of births in Singapore and with the increase in the number of children registered in schools, I do not see any increase in this provision for 1968 as against 1967. Can the Minister say why the provision for 1968 is not increased?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Sir, this subhead refers to Teachers of Religion in Malay schools. In 1968, there will be an increase of 27 Malay-medium classes in the secondary level, but a decrease of 13 Malay-medium classes in the primary level. The net increase is, therefore, only 14 classes. There is provision in 1968 for employing a total of 41 religious teachers and this number is adequate for our needs.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff(In Malay): With that explanation, Sir, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0601 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1431.

Column: 734



    It is generally known that with a few exceptions, school for school, student for student, and even teacher for teacher, the aided schools seem to be doing better than the Government schools. Why is this so? I have no doubt the Minister for Education will be able to give good reasons for this. But having good reasons for the present state of affairs is one thing and finding means to improve the situation is another. It is to be noted that 25 per cent of our Budget, which is equivalent to $151 million, is to be expended on education. If we are to get equitable returns for this large sum of money spent, and more important, if we are to ensure that our younger generation will grow up to be well-educated, well-trained and well-disciplined citizens of the future, then we must see to it that every child in school is given good education and that every teacher is of the right calibre and is playing his expected role in our education system. That this is not so is seen in the apparent disparity in educational standards between aided schools and Government schools generally.

    One of the factors responsible for this unsatisfactory state of affairs is the quality of teachers taken in by the Teachers' Training College. At one time, due to the rapid increase in the number of schools and due to the shortage of suitably qualified personnel to be trained as teachers, the Teachers' Training College had little choice. The situation is now quite different. With the large number of Senior Cambridge and Middle School graduates coming into the employment market every year, it is now possible to recruit teachers-in-training who are not only well qualified academically but also capable and dedicated in moulding the children to become useful and responsible citizens. In this respect, Sir, the conduct of teachers must first be re-examined. It is not my intention to criticise the teaching profession for the members of which I have the highest regard, and indeed there are a good number of teachers who are above reproach. The House will no doubt agree that wearing tight

Column: 735

jeans and drain-pipe trousers and the keeping of long hair by teachers are not good examples for the children. These and other undesirable forms of conduct of some teachers during school hours are frowned upon not only by parents but also by respected and dedicated members of the noble profession. I therefore urge that such elements be seriously looked into by the Minister. I have no doubt that any measures taken by him will have the support of the parents and the teachers' unions, for this will help to preserve the dignity and respect of the profession.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, I agree with many of the remarks made by the Member for Anson.

    The Minister for Health (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): I strongly agree.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: I can assure him that every possible step is being taken to improve the quality of teachers. I think there are many reasons why the performance of the aided schools is better compared with the Government schools. I do not think there will be enough time in this House to dwell in detail on the factors. But suffice it to say that aided schools, as a whole, have a more stable staff as the teachers are not liable to be transferred from school to school and, in many respects, the teaching staff are more dedicated, if not for other reasons, at least for their own survival.

    I agree with the Member for Anson that the standard of education in schools depends to a large extent on the quality of the teachers and, in this respect, various steps have been taken by the Ministry to ensure that the teachers recruited are of a high quality and that those who have been recruited in the past will be brought up to the sane level. For this, various kinds of in-service courses are being organised by the Teachers' Training College.

    As for the appearance of teachers in schools, I think the Member for Anson will recall that at the sitting of Parliament in September, I made a statement

Column: 736

that teachers should dress decorously rather than decoratively. Subsequent to that, I had a discussion with all the teachers' unions in Singapore. I am glad to say that all of them expressed support. The Singapore Teachers' Union, in fact, have circulated some rules for the guidance of their members as to the way teachers should dress and behave in schools. When the new term begins in January, if the Member for Anson will go round and visit some of the schools, I am sure he will notice an appreciable difference.

    Mr Govindaswamy: I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff(In Malay): Sir, I beg to move,

    The allocation for free text-books and stationery for pupils for 1968 is no different from the amount for 1967. Many schools are unable to provide free text-books to pupils who deserve them. In Kampong Kembangan Constituency, there are schools where a number of students deserve to get free text-books but, unfortunately, they could not be given and their applications were refused. Therefore, I would request the Minister to increase the allocation for Kampong Kembangan in view of the fact that the parents there are in the low salary bracket and in order that children who deserve to get free text-books can continue their education in the schools.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Sir, the school enrolment will increase by about 15,000 next year and the provision for the free text-book scheme is the same for 1967. However, this does not necessarily mean that fewer pupils will receive the loan of text-books. This is because schools have accumulated large stocks of books over the last few years and the funds provided will be utilised for the purchase of new books and for the replacement of old books which are worn out.

    The conditions for the issue of textbooks on loan to students are made in such a way as to enable deserving students to enjoy this privilege on a priority basis. Although the Member for Kampong Kembangan has mentioned several deserving pupils in his constituency not being able to receive assistance under this scheme, I can assure him that if these pupils are really deserving of help, as he has said, and if he can supply me with the details, I am quite prepared to look into these few cases that he has in mind.

3.15 p.m.

    But as he is aware, the financial resources of the State are limited, It is not possible to get something more for the free text-book scheme without affecting some other Ministry or some other items of expenditure which are equally important.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff(In Malay): With that assurance by the Minister, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0601 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (3) of subhead 2124.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the education policy of the Government of Singapore gives equal treatment to all four streams of education - Malay, Chinese, Tamil and English. The Malay schools receive Government assistance. Recently a Committee was set up to collect funds for the building of a secondary school. Can the Minister say whether a similar grant-in-aid will be given to the proposed Islamic Secondary School?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Islamic Secondary School mentioned by the Member for Kampong Kembangan has not yet been built, it is not likely that it will come into existence in 1968. So the question of grant-in-aid for this school does not therefore

Column: 738

affect the current Estimates. Consideration for a grant-in-aid can only be given when the school is established and application for aid is submitted. There are conditions to be met before aid can be given. It is not possible at this juncture to give blanket approval for a project which has not yet materialised.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff(In Malay): I beg leave to withdraw.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the educational measures that have been put into practice are more or less based on the 1959 educational policy. But we are aware that certain policies have not been carried out, one of which relates to teacher training. Every year, we spend quite a large sum of money on teacher training. We know that the Teachers' Training College, apart from providing training in teaching methods, has not provided the most important kind of training, namely, the development of the outlook of teachers. In view of the fact that Singapore has been independent for nearly three years now, we would like all students to realise that this country belongs to them. It is, therefore, very important that we should instil national consciousness in their minds. It follows that the trainee teachers must also be imbued with this quality, otherwise the minds of their pupils will not he instilled with national consciousness. I remember that not long ago certain Chinese schools did quite well in this aspect of education, and they instilled a feeling of patriotism in their pupils. Of course, many schools are teaching civics and other subjects pertaining to patriotism, but if the trainee teachers themselves are not properly taught in this respect, they will not cut a good image with their students. I would like to quote from the booklet "The Tasks

Column: 739

Ahead - P.A.P.'s Five-Year Plan 1959-1964" under the chapter of "Spring Source of Our Nation" to show that certain policies or measures have not been carried out:

    Our teachers must therefore realise the important role they play in the building of a united democratic Malayan nation. And they must learn that their duties do not end with the imparting of text-book knowledge. They have a whole generation of children to mould into a national pattern. To do this successfully, they themselves must acquire those social values and convictions which they will have to impart to the young. It is unlikely that we shall succeed in building a Malayan nation unless teachers know exactly what this means and understand exactly what they have to do.'

Therefore, I feel that now that we have gained independence, our young generation must be imbued with national consciousness and the persons who teach them are the teachers. But there is a lack of such training for teachers. They themselves have not realised the important task of education. They treat it as a means of livelihood and not as their vocation or as part of their duties. They treat their work in the same routine manner as the civil servants. The Teachers' Training College should institute such training in the courses for teachers in the coming year so that our young generation can better absorb social values and convictions.

    There is another aspect in the P.A.P.'s educational policy which has not been carried out, namely, the main objective of training our students to become useful citizens so that they can adapt themselves to our economic policies and the task of nation building. They will be the next generation who will lay down the foundations of a socialist society. If our industrial capacity is weak, this is because of the educational policy under the colonial regime which was very backward. In order to expand our industry and economy, we must make full use of our talents.
